ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Ability to understand and evaluate academic papers. Cross over between politics and economics.
Aside from learning about the political economy of development literature, i.e. content, I found the class discussion really improved my ability to analyse economics papers.
Interesting overview of political economy of development, I appreciated how the professors moved through discussions of models and empirical methods
well-balanced class with both theory and empirics.
Great content, comprehensively tackling the main topics in PED in the literature.

I learned about models of political economy, political agency, citizen candidate, probabilistic voting, median voter, etc. I also read many empirical studies, and analyzed their strengths and weaknesses. I learned to appreciate the political component of many economic problems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Quite long class, good size of class, problem sets could be more related to class material.

Strengths: quality of analysis in teaching and discussion, focus on detail

Weaknesses: I think the classes could be shorter or even split into two shorter classes. I also found some of the theoretical material difficult to follow but as a non-PhD student I'm not the target audience necessarily!

- strength: Very well structured.
- potential improvement: it'd be better if this course could focus more about the students' research.

Such a great tandem of instructors, each giving their insight and becoming extremely complimentary. Such a great class full of very interesting content. I would maybe recommend the instructors to post their lecture notes on a timely manner on canvas so that we can access them before and after the class.

The strengths are the content and the lecturers. They were both amazing, and the content was always fascinating.

In terms of improvement, I think the course structure is a bit too "lecture-style" than I would have liked. I think I would have learned more if we spent more class time workshopping research ideas or having critical discussions of papers, rather than just listening lecture. Which pains me to say because I loved the lectures, but I do wonder how much of it I retained. 

On a similar note, I wish the class met twice a week for 1.25 hours rather than once a week for 2.25 hours. I think I would have had more time to process the material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this course addresses many different topics in political economy and the sections are thoughtfully planned
Absoilutely, such an incredible class with great instructors.
Yes, definitely. I think many economics students could benefit from exposure to political economy concepts, and I think this course is taught quite well.
